paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75
paragraph.content: You are entering into a new transaction to increase the amount of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> previously provided to you. Your home is the security for this new transaction. You have a legal right under Federal law to cancel this new transaction, without cost, within three business days from whichever of the following events occurs last:

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75-1
paragraph.content: the date of this new transaction, which is ______; or

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75-2
paragraph.content: the date you received your new Truth in Lending disclosures; or

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75-3
paragraph.content: the date you received this notice of your right to cancel.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75-p76
paragraph.content: If you cancel this new transaction, it will not affect any amount that you presently owe. Your home is the security for that amount. Within 20 calendar days after we receive your notice of cancellation of this new transaction, we must take the steps necessary to reflect the fact that your home does not secure the increase of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref>. We must also return any money you have given to us or anyone else in connection with this new transaction.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75-p77
paragraph.content: You may keep any money we have given you in this new transaction until we have done the things mentioned above, but you must then offer to return the money at the address below.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h6-p75-p78
paragraph.content: If we do not take possession of the money within 20 calendar days of your offer, you may keep it without further obligation.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h7-p79
paragraph.content: If you decide to cancel this new transaction, you may do so by notifying us in writing, at

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h7-p80

paragraph.label: 1026-H-9-h7-p81
paragraph.content: (<ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditor</ref>'s name and business address).

Keep one copy of this notice because it contains important information about your rights.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h9

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h9-p95
paragraph.content: • Your interest rate will be based on an index rate plus a margin.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h9-p96
paragraph.content: • Your payment will be based on the interest rate, loan balance, and loan term.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h9-p97
paragraph.content: —The interest rate will be based on the weekly average yield on United <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">States</ref> Treasury securities adjusted to a constant maturity of 1 year (your index), plus our margin. Ask us for our current interest rate and margin.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h9-p98
paragraph.content: —Information about the index rate is published weekly in the Wall Street Journal.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h9-p99
paragraph.content: • Your interest rate will equal the index rate plus our margin unless your interest rate “caps” limit the amount of change in the interest rate.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h10
paragraph.title: How Your Interest Rate Can Change

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h10-p100
paragraph.content: • Your interest rate can change yearly.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h10-p101
paragraph.content: • Your interest rate cannot increase or decrease more than 2 percentage points per year.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h10-p102
paragraph.content: • Your interest rate cannot increase or decrease more than 5 percentage points over the term of the loan.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h11
paragraph.title: How Your Monthly Payment Can Change

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h11-p103
paragraph.content: • Your monthly payment can increase or decrease substantially based on annual changes in the interest rate.

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h11-p104
paragraph.content: • [For example, on a $10,000, 30-year loan with an initial interest rate of 12.41 percent in effect in July 1996, the maximum amount that the interest rate can rise under this program is 5 percentage points, to 17.41 percent, and the monthly payment can rise from a first-year payment of $106.03 to a maximum of $145.34 in the fourth year. To see what your payment is, divide your mortgage amount by $10,000; then multiply the monthly payment by that amount. (For example, the monthly payment for a mortgage amount of $60,000 would be: $60,000 ÷ $10,000 = 6; 6 × 106.03 = $636.18 per month.)

paragraph.label: 1026-H-14-h11-p105
paragraph.content: • You will be notified in writing 25 days before the annual payment adjustment may be made. This notice will contain information about your interest rates, payment amount and loan balance.]

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v
paragraph.content: An extension of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> made by:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-A
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> designated as a Community Development Financial Institution, as defined under <ref target="CFR:12-1805-104" reftype="external">12 CFR 1805.104</ref>(h);

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-B
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> designated as a <ref target="1026-2-a-18" reftype="term">Downpayment</ref> Assistance through Secondary Financing Provider, pursuant to <ref target="CFR:24-200-194" reftype="external">24 CFR 200.194</ref>(a), operating in accordance with regulations prescribed by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development applicable to such <ref target="1026-2-a-22" reftype="term">persons</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-C
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> designated as a Community Housing Development Organization provided that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> has entered into a commitment with a participating jurisdiction and is undertaking a project under the HOME program, pursuant to the provisions of <ref target="CFR:24-92-300" reftype="external">24 CFR 92.300</ref>(a), and as the terms community housing development organization, commitment, participating jurisdiction, and project are defined under <ref target="CFR:24-92-2" reftype="external">24 CFR 92.2</ref>; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-D
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> with a tax exemption ruling or determination letter from the Internal Revenue Service under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (<ref target="USC:26-501" reftype="external">26 U.S.C. 501</ref>(c)(3); <ref target="CFR:26-1-501" reftype="external">26 CFR 1.501</ref>(c)(3)-1), provided that:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-D-1
paragraph.content: During the calendar year preceding receipt of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s application, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> extended <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> secured by a <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> no more than 200 times;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-D-2
paragraph.content: During the calendar year preceding receipt of the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s application, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> extended <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> secured by a <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> only to <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> with income that did not exceed the low- and moderate-income household limit as established pursuant to section 102 of the Housing and Community Development <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref> of 1974 (<ref target="USC:42-5302" reftype="external">42 U.S.C. 5302</ref>(a)(20)) and amended from time to time by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, pursuant to <ref target="CFR:24-570-3" reftype="external">24 CFR 570.3</ref>;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-D-3
paragraph.content: The extension of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> is to a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> with income that does not exceed the household limit specified in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-a-3-v-D-2" reftype="internal">(a)(3)(v)(D)(2)</ref> of this section; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-a-3-v-D-4
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> determines, in accordance with written procedures, that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> has a reasonable ability to repay the extension of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-i
paragraph.title: Prohibition on financing single-premium credit insurance.
paragraph.content: Prohibition on financing single-premium <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> insurance.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-i-1
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> may not finance, directly or indirectly, any premiums or fees for <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> insurance in connection with a <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> transaction secured by a <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> (including a home equity line of <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> secured by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s principal <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref>). This prohibition does not apply to <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> insurance for which premiums or fees are calculated and paid in full on a monthly basis.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-i-2
paragraph.content: For purposes of this paragraph <ref target="1026-36-i" reftype="internal">(i)</ref>, “<ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> insurance”:

paragraph.label: 1026-36-i-2-i
paragraph.content: Means <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> life, <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> disability, <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> unemployment, or <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> property insurance, or any other accident, loss-of-income, life, or health insurance, or any payments directly or indirectly for any debt cancellation or suspension agreement or contract, but

paragraph.label: 1026-36-i-2-ii
paragraph.content: Excludes <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> unemployment insurance for which the unemployment insurance premiums are reasonable, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> receives no direct or indirect <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> in connection with the unemployment insurance premiums, and the unemployment insurance premiums are paid pursuant to a separate insurance contract and are not paid to an <ref target="1026-32-b-5" reftype="term">affiliate</ref> of the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-a
paragraph.content: Adjusted Balance Method

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-p1
paragraph.content: We figure [a portion of] the finance charge on your account by applying the <ref target="1026-2-a-21" reftype="term">periodic rate</ref> to the “adjusted balance” of your account. We get the “adjusted balance” by taking the balance you owed at the end of the previous <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref> and subtracting [any unpaid finance charges and] any payments and <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credits</ref> received during the present <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-b
paragraph.content: Previous Balance Method

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-p2
paragraph.content: We figure [a portion of] the finance charge on your account by applying the <ref target="1026-2-a-21" reftype="term">periodic rate</ref> to the amount you owe at the beginning of each <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref> [minus any unpaid finance charges]. We do not subtract any payments or <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credits</ref> received during the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>. [The amount of payments and <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credits</ref> to your account this <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref> was $ ____.]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-c
paragraph.content: Average Daily Balance Method (Excluding Current Transactions)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-p3
paragraph.content: We figure [a portion of] the finance charge on your account by applying the <ref target="1026-2-a-21" reftype="term">periodic rate</ref> to the “average daily balance” of your account (excluding current transactions). To get the “average daily balance” we take the beginning balance of your account each day and subtract any payments or <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credits</ref> [and any unpaid finance charges]. We do not add in any new [purchases/advances/loans]. This gives us the daily balance. Then, we add all the daily balances for the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref> together and divide the total by the number of days in the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>. This gives us the “average daily balance.”

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-d
paragraph.content: Average Daily Balance Method (Including Current Transactions)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-p4
paragraph.content: We figure [a portion of] the finance charge on your account by applying the <ref target="1026-2-a-21" reftype="term">periodic rate</ref> to the “average daily balance” of your account (including current transactions). To get the “average daily balance” we take the beginning balance of your account each day, add any new [purchases/advances/loans], and subtract any payments or <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credits</ref>, [and unpaid finance charges]. This gives us the daily balance. Then, we add up all the daily balances for the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref> and divide the total by the number of days in the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>. This gives us the “average daily balance.”

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-e
paragraph.content: Ending Balance Method

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-p5
paragraph.content: We figure [a portion of] the finance charge on your account by applying the <ref target="1026-2-a-21" reftype="term">periodic rate</ref> to the amount you owe at the end of each <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref> (including new purchases and deducting payments and <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credits</ref> made during the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>).

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-f
paragraph.content: Daily Balance Method (Including Current Transactions)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1-p6
paragraph.content: We figure [a portion of] the finance charge on your account by applying the <ref target="1026-2-a-21" reftype="term">periodic rate</ref> to the “daily balance” of your account for each day in the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>. To get the “daily balance” we take the beginning balance of your account each day, add any new [purchases/advances/fees], and subtract [any unpaid finance charges and] any payments or <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credits</ref>. This gives us the daily balance.

appendixSection.label: 1026-G-1(A)
appendixSection.subject: G-1(A)—Balance Computation Methods Model Clauses (Plans Other Than Home-Equity Plans)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1(A)-a
paragraph.content: Adjusted Balance Method

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1(A)-p7
paragraph.content: We figure the interest charge on your account by applying the <ref target="1026-2-a-21" reftype="term">periodic rate</ref> to the “adjusted balance” of your account. We get the “adjusted balance” by taking the balance you owed at the end of the previous <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref> and subtracting [any unpaid interest or other finance charges and] any payments and <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credits</ref> received during the present <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>.

We do not subtract any payments or <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credits</ref> received during the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1(A)-c

To get the “average daily balance” we take the beginning balance of your account each day and subtract [any unpaid interest or other finance charges and] any payments or <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credits</ref>. We do not add in any new [purchases/advances/fees]. This gives us the daily balance. Then, we add all the daily balances for the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref> together and divide the total by the number of days in the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>. This gives us the “average daily balance.”

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1(A)-d
paragraph.content: Average Daily Balance Method (Including Current Transactions)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1(A)-p10
paragraph.content: We figure the interest charge on your account by applying the <ref target="1026-2-a-21" reftype="term">periodic rate</ref> to the “average daily balance” of your account. To get the “average daily balance” we take the beginning balance of your account each day, add any new [purchases/advances/fees], and subtract [any unpaid interest or other finance charges and] any payments or <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credits</ref>. This gives us the daily balance. Then, we add up all the daily balances for the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref> and divide the total by the number of days in the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>. This gives us the “average daily balance.”

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1(A)-e
paragraph.content: Ending Balance Method

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1(A)-p11
paragraph.content: We figure the interest charge on your account by applying the <ref target="1026-2-a-21" reftype="term">periodic rate</ref> to the amount you owe at the end of each <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref> (including new [purchases/advances/fees] and deducting payments and <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credits</ref> made during the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>).

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1(A)-f
paragraph.content: Daily Balance Method (Including Current Transactions)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-1(A)-p12
paragraph.content: We figure the interest charge on your account by applying the <ref target="1026-2-a-21" reftype="term">periodic rate</ref> to the “daily balance” of your account for each day in the <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>. To get the “daily balance” we take the beginning balance of your account each day, add any new [purchases/advances/fees], and subtract [any unpaid interest or other finance charges and] any payments or <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credits</ref>. This gives us the daily balance.

appendixSection.label: 1026-G-3
appendixSection.subject: G-3—Long-Form Billing-Error Rights Model Form (Home-Equity Plans)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h2
paragraph.title: KEEP THIS NOTICE FOR FUTURE USE

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h2-p18
paragraph.content: This notice contains important information about your rights and our responsibilities under the Fair <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">Credit</ref> Billing <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3
paragraph.title: Notify Us in Case of Errors or Questions About Your Bill

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3-p19
paragraph.content: If you think your bill is wrong, or if you need more information about a transaction on your bill, write us [on a separate sheet] at [address] [the address listed on your bill]. Write to us as soon as possible. We must hear from you no later than 60 days after we sent you the first bill on which the error or problem appeared. [You may also contact us on the Web: [<ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditor</ref> Web or email address]] You can telephone us, but doing so will not preserve your rights.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3-p20
paragraph.content: In your letter, give us the following information:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3-p21
paragraph.content: • Your name and account number.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3-p22
paragraph.content: • The dollar amount of the suspected error.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3-p23
paragraph.content: • Describe the error and explain, if you can, why you believe there is an error. If you need more information, describe the item you are not sure about.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h3-p24
paragraph.content: If you have authorized us to pay your <ref target="1026-2-a-15-i" reftype="term">credit card</ref> bill automatically from your savings or checking account, you can stop the payment on any amount you think is wrong. To stop the payment your letter must reach us three business days before the automatic payment is scheduled to occur.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h4
paragraph.title: Your Rights and Our Responsibilities After We Receive Your Written Notice

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h4-p25
paragraph.content: We must acknowledge your letter within 30 days, unless we have corrected the error by then. Within 90 days, we must either correct the error or explain why we believe the bill was correct.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h4-p26
paragraph.content: After we receive your letter, we cannot try to collect any amount you question, or report you as delinquent. We can continue to bill you for the amount you question, including finance charges, and we can apply any unpaid amount against your <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> limit. You do not have to pay any questioned amount while we are investigating, but you are still obligated to pay the parts of your bill that are not in question.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h4-p27
paragraph.content: If we find that we made a mistake on your bill, you will not have to pay any finance charges related to any questioned amount. If we didn't make a mistake, you may have to pay finance charges, and you will have to make up any missed payments on the questioned amount. In either case, we will send you a statement of the amount you owe and the date that it is due.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h4-p28
paragraph.content: If you fail to pay the amount that we think you owe, we may report you as delinquent. However, if our explanation does not satisfy you and you write to us within ten days telling us that you still refuse to pay, we must tell anyone we report you to that you have a question about your bill. And, we must tell you the name of anyone we reported you to. We must tell anyone we report you to that the matter has been settled between us when it finally is.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h4-p29
paragraph.content: If we don't follow these rules, we can't collect the first $50 of the questioned amount, even if your bill was correct.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h5
paragraph.title: Special Rule for Credit Card Purchases

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h5-p30
paragraph.content: If you have a problem with the quality of property or services that you purchased with a <ref target="1026-2-a-15-i" reftype="term">credit card</ref>, and you have tried in good faith to correct the problem with the merchant, you may have the right not to pay the remaining amount due on the property or services.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h5-p31
paragraph.content: There are two limitations on this right:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h5-p31-a
paragraph.content: You must have made the purchase in your home <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">state</ref> or, if not within your home <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">state</ref> within 100 miles of your current mailing address; and

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h5-p31-b
paragraph.content: The purchase price must have been more than $50.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3-h5-p31-p32
paragraph.content: These limitations do not apply if we own or operate the merchant, or if we mailed you the <ref target="1026-2-a-2" reftype="term">advertisement</ref> for the property or services.

appendixSection.label: 1026-G-3(A)
appendixSection.subject: G-3(A)—Long-Form Billing-Error Rights Model Form (Plans Other Than Home-Equity Plans)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h6
paragraph.title: Your Billing Rights: Keep This Document For Future Use

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h6-p33
paragraph.content: This notice tells you about your rights and our responsibilities under the Fair <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">Credit</ref> Billing <ref target="1026-2-a-1" reftype="term">Act</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7
paragraph.title: What To Do If You Find A Mistake On Your Statement

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p34
paragraph.content: If you think there is an error on your statement, write to us at:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p35
paragraph.content: [<ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditor</ref> Name]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p36
paragraph.content: [<ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditor</ref> Address]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p37
paragraph.content: [You may also contact us on the Web: [<ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditor</ref> Web or email address]]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p38
paragraph.content: In your letter, give us the following information:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p39
paragraph.content: • Account information: Your name and account number.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p40
paragraph.content: • Dollar amount: The dollar amount of the suspected error.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p41
paragraph.content: • Description of problem: If you think there is an error on your bill, describe what you believe is wrong and why you believe it is a mistake.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p42
paragraph.content: You must contact us:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p43
paragraph.content: • Within 60 days after the error appeared on your statement.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p44
paragraph.content: • At least 3 business days before an automated payment is scheduled, if you want to stop payment on the amount you think is wrong.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h7-p45
paragraph.content: You must notify us of any potential errors in writing [or electronically]. You may call us, but if you do we are not required to investigate any potential errors and you may have to pay the amount in question.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8
paragraph.title: What Will Happen After We Receive Your Letter

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46
paragraph.content: When we receive your letter, we must do two things:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-1
paragraph.content: Within 30 days of receiving your letter, we must tell you that we received your letter. We will also tell you if we have already corrected the error.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-2
paragraph.content: Within 90 days of receiving your letter, we must either correct the error or explain to you why we believe the bill is correct.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p47
paragraph.content: While we investigate whether or not there has been an error:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p48
paragraph.content: • We cannot try to collect the amount in question, or report you as delinquent on that amount.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p49
paragraph.content: • The charge in question may remain on your statement, and we may continue to charge you interest on that amount.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p50
paragraph.content: • While you do not have to pay the amount in question, you are responsible for the remainder of your balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p51
paragraph.content: • We can apply any unpaid amount against your <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> limit.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p52
paragraph.content: After we finish our investigation, one of two things will happen:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p53
paragraph.content: • If we made a mistake: You will not have to pay the amount in question or any interest or other fees related to that amount.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p54
paragraph.content: • If we do not believe there was a mistake: You will have to pay the amount in question, along with applicable interest and fees. We will send you a statement of the amount you owe and the date payment is due. We may then report you as delinquent if you do not pay the amount we think you owe.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p55
paragraph.content: If you receive our explanation but still believe your bill is wrong, you must write to us within 10 days telling us that you still refuse to pay. If you do so, we cannot report you as delinquent without also reporting that you are questioning your bill. We must tell you the name of anyone to whom we reported you as delinquent, and we must let those organizations know when the matter has been settled between us.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h8-p46-p56
paragraph.content: If we do not follow all of the rules above, you do not have to pay the first $50 of the amount you question even if your bill is correct.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9
paragraph.title: Your Rights If You Are Dissatisfied With Your Credit Card Purchases

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p57
paragraph.content: If you are dissatisfied with the goods or services that you have purchased with your <ref target="1026-2-a-15-i" reftype="term">credit card</ref>, and you have tried in good faith to correct the problem with the merchant, you may have the right not to pay the remaining amount due on the purchase.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58
paragraph.content: To use this right, all of the following must be true:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-1
paragraph.content: The purchase must have been made in your home <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">state</ref> or within 100 miles of your current mailing address, and the purchase price must have been more than $50. (Note: Neither of these are necessary if your purchase was based on an <ref target="1026-2-a-2" reftype="term">advertisement</ref> we mailed to you, or if we own the company that sold you the goods or services.)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-2
paragraph.content: You must have used your <ref target="1026-2-a-15-i" reftype="term">credit card</ref> for the purchase. Purchases made with cash advances from an ATM or with a check that accesses your <ref target="1026-2-a-15-i" reftype="term">credit card</ref> account do not qualify.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-3
paragraph.content: You must not yet have fully paid for the purchase.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-p59
paragraph.content: If all of the criteria above are met and you are still dissatisfied with the purchase, contact us in writing [or electronically] at:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-p60
paragraph.content: [<ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditor</ref> Name]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-p61
paragraph.content: [<ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditor</ref> Address]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-p62
paragraph.content: [[<ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditor</ref> Web or email address]]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-3(A)-h9-p58-p63
paragraph.content: While we investigate, the same rules apply to the disputed amount as discussed above. After we finish our investigation, we will tell you our decision. At that point, if we think you owe an amount and you do not pay, we may report you as delinquent.

paragraph.content: You must contact us within 60 days after the error appeared on your statement.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h13-p80
paragraph.content: You must notify us of any potential errors in writing [or electronically]. You may call us, but if you do we are not required to investigate any potential errors and you may have to pay the amount in question.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h13-p81
paragraph.content: While we investigate whether or not there has been an error, the following are true:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h13-p82
paragraph.content: • We cannot try to collect the amount in question, or report you as delinquent on that amount.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h13-p83
paragraph.content: • The charge in question may remain on your statement, and we may continue to charge you interest on that amount. But, if we determine that we made a mistake, you will not have to pay the amount in question or any interest or other fees related to that amount.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h13-p84
paragraph.content: • While you do not have to pay the amount in question, you are responsible for the remainder of your balance.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h13-p85
paragraph.content: • We can apply any unpaid amount against your <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> limit.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h14
paragraph.title: Your Rights If You Are Dissatisfied With Your Credit Card Purchases

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h14-p86
paragraph.content: If you are dissatisfied with the goods or services that you have purchased with your <ref target="1026-2-a-15-i" reftype="term">credit card</ref>, and you have tried in good faith to correct the problem with the merchant, you may have the right not to pay the remaining amount due on the purchase.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h14-p87
paragraph.content: To use this right, all of the following must be true:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h14-p87-1
paragraph.content: The purchase must have been made in your home <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">state</ref> or within 100 miles of your current mailing address, and the purchase price must have been more than $50. (Note: Neither of these is necessary if your purchase was based on an <ref target="1026-2-a-2" reftype="term">advertisement</ref> we mailed to you, or if we own the company that sold you the goods or services.)

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h14-p87-2
paragraph.content: You must have used your <ref target="1026-2-a-15-i" reftype="term">credit card</ref> for the purchase. Purchases made with cash advances from an ATM or with a check that accesses your <ref target="1026-2-a-15-i" reftype="term">credit card</ref> account do not qualify.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h14-p87-3
paragraph.content: You must not yet have fully paid for the purchase.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h14-p87-p88
paragraph.content: If all of the criteria above are met and you are still dissatisfied with the purchase, contact us in writing [or electronically] at:

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h14-p87-p89
paragraph.content: [<ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditor</ref> Name]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h14-p87-p90
paragraph.content: [<ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditor</ref> Address]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h14-p87-p91
paragraph.content: [[<ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditor</ref> Web address]]

paragraph.label: 1026-G-4(A)-h14-p87-p92
paragraph.content: While we investigate, the same rules apply to the disputed amount as discussed above. After we finish our investigation, we will tell you our decision. At that point, if we think you owe an amount and you do not pay we may report you as delinquent.

We may also increase your APRs to the Penalty APR of XX.XX%. You will only pay one fee per <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">billing cycle</ref>, even if you go over your limit multiple times in the same <ref target="1026-2-a-4" reftype="term">cycle</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-G-25(A)-h15-p155

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-iii
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> considers at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly debt-to-income ratio or residual income and verifies the debt obligations and income used to determine that ratio in accordance with paragraph <ref target="1026-43-c-7" reftype="internal">(c)(7)</ref> of this section, except that the calculation of the payment on the <ref target="1026-43-b-1" reftype="term">covered transaction</ref> for purposes of determining the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s total monthly debt obligations in (c)(7)(i)(A) shall be determined in accordance with paragraph <ref target="1026-43-f" reftype="internal">(f)</ref>(iv)(A) of this section, together with the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly payments for all <ref target="1026-43-b-8" reftype="term">mortgage-related obligations</ref> and excluding the balloon payment;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-f-1-ii
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> determines at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> can make all of the scheduled payments under the terms of the legal obligation, as described in paragraph <ref target="1026-43-f-1-iv" reftype="internal">(f)(1)(iv)</ref> of this section, together with the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly payments for all <ref target="1026-43-b-8" reftype="term">mortgage-related obligations</ref> and excluding the balloon payment, from the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s current or reasonably expected income or assets other than the <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> that secures the loan;

paragraph.label: 1026-43-d-2-i
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> for the standard mortgage is the current holder of the existing non-standard mortgage or the servicer acting on behalf of the current holder;

paragraph.label: 1026-35-b-2-iv-A
paragraph.content: A county is “rural” during a calendar year if it is neither in a metropolitan statistical area nor in a micropolitan statistical area that is adjacent to a metropolitan statistical area, as those terms are defined by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget and as they are applied under currently applicable Urban Influence Codes (UICs), established by the United <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">States</ref> Department of Agriculture's Economic Research Service (USDA-ERS). A <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> may rely as a safe harbor on the list of counties published by the <ref target="1026-2-a-5" reftype="term">Bureau</ref> to determine whether a county qualifies as “rural” for a particular calendar year.

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B-2
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-36-a-1-ii" reftype="term">individual loan originator</ref> was a <ref target="1026-36-a-1-i" reftype="term">loan originator</ref> for ten or fewer transactions subject to this paragraph <ref target="1026-36-d" reftype="internal">(d)</ref> consummated during the 12-month period preceding the date of the <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> determination.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-d-1-i
paragraph.title: In general.
paragraph.content: In general. For purposes of this paragraph <ref target="1026-20-d" reftype="internal">(d)</ref>, an adjustable-rate mortgage or “ARM” is a closed-end <ref target="1026-2-a-12" reftype="term">consumer credit</ref> transaction secured by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s principal <ref target="1026-2-a-19" reftype="term">dwelling</ref> in which the annual percentage rate may increase after <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-32-b-1-iv
paragraph.content: Premiums or other charges payable at or before <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref> for any <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> life, <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> disability, <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> unemployment, or <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> property insurance, or any other life, accident, health, or loss-of-income insurance for which the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> is a beneficiary, or any payments directly or indirectly for any debt cancellation or suspension agreement or contract;

paragraph.label: 1026-36-d-1-iv-B-1
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> paid to an <ref target="1026-36-a-1-ii" reftype="term">individual loan originator</ref> pursuant to this paragraph <ref target="1026-36-d-1-iv" reftype="internal">(d)(1)(iv)</ref> does not, in the aggregate, exceed 10 percent of the <ref target="1026-36-a-1-ii" reftype="term">individual loan originator</ref>'s total <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> corresponding to the time period for which the <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> under the non-deferred profits-based <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> plan is paid; or

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2
paragraph.title: Limits on prepayment penalties.
paragraph.content: Limits on <ref target="1026-43-b-10" reftype="term">prepayment penalties</ref>. A <ref target="1026-43-b-10" reftype="term">prepayment penalty</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-i
paragraph.content: Must not apply after the three-year period following <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-ii
paragraph.content: Must not exceed the following percentages of the amount of the outstanding loan balance prepaid:

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: 2 percent, if incurred during the first two years following <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>; and

paragraph.label: 1026-43-g-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: 1 percent, if incurred during the third year following <ref target="1026-2-a-13" reftype="term">consummation</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-43-c-2-viii
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> history.

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii
paragraph.content: A table containing the following information:

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-A
paragraph.content: The current and new interest rates;

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-B
paragraph.content: The current and new payments and the date the first new payment is due; and

paragraph.label: 1026-20-c-2-ii-C
paragraph.content: For interest-only or negatively-amortizing payments, the amount of the current and new payment allocated to principal, interest, and taxes and insurance in escrow, as applicable. The current payment allocation disclosed shall be the payment allocation for the last payment prior to the date of the disclosure. The new payment allocation disclosed shall be the expected payment allocation for the first payment for which the new interest rate will apply.

appendix.label: 1026-Q
appendix.appendixTitle: Appendix Q to Part 1026—Standards for Determining Monthly Debt and Income

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A
paragraph.content: Stability of Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-1
paragraph.title: Effective Income.
paragraph.content: Effective Income. Income may not be used in calculating the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income ratios if it comes from any source that cannot be verified, is not stable, or will not continue.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-2
paragraph.title: Verifying Employment History.
paragraph.content: Verifying Employment History.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-2-a
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must verify the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s employment for the most recent two full years, and the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> must:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-2-a-i
paragraph.content: Explain any gaps in employment that span one or more months, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-2-a-ii
paragraph.content: Indicate if he/she was in school or the military for the recent two full years, providing evidence supporting this claim, such as college transcripts, or discharge papers.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-2-b
paragraph.content: Allowances can be made for seasonal employment, typical for the building trades and agriculture, if documented by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-2-p2
paragraph.content: ```note Note: A <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> with a 25 percent or greater ownership interest in a business is considered self-employed and will be evaluated as a self-employed <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> for underwriting purposes. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3
paragraph.title: Analyzing a Consumer's Employment Record.
paragraph.content: Analyzing a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref>'s Employment Record.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a
paragraph.content: When analyzing the probability of continued employment, <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditors</ref> must examine:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-i
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s past employment record;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Qualifications for the position;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-iii
paragraph.content: Previous training and education; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-a-iv
paragraph.content: The employer's confirmation of continued employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-3-b
paragraph.content: Favorably consider a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> for a mortgage if he/she changes jobs frequently within the same line of work, but continues to advance in income or benefits. In this analysis, income stability takes precedence over job stability.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4
paragraph.title: Consumers Returning to Work After an Extended Absence.
paragraph.content: <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumers</ref> Returning to Work After an Extended Absence. A <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income may be considered effective and stable when recently returning to work after an extended absence if he/she:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-a
paragraph.content: Is employed in the current job for six months or longer; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-b
paragraph.content: Can document a two-year work history prior to an absence from employment using:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-b-i
paragraph.content: Traditional employment verifications; and/or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-b-ii
paragraph.content: Copies of IRS Form W-2s or pay stubs.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-b-p3
paragraph.content: ```note Note: An acceptable employment situation includes individuals who took several years off from employment to raise children, then returned to the workforce. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-A-4-c
paragraph.content: Important: Situations not meeting the criteria listed above may not be used in qualifying. Extended absence is defined as six months.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B
paragraph.content: Salary, Wage and Other Forms of Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-1
paragraph.title: General Policy on Consumer Income Analysis.
paragraph.content: General Policy on <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref> Income Analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-1-a
paragraph.content: The income of each <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> who will be obligated for the mortgage debt must be analyzed to determine whether his/her income level can be reasonably expected to continue through at least the first three years of the mortgage loan.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-1-b
paragraph.content: In most cases, a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income is limited to salaries or wages. Income from other sources can be considered as effective, when properly verified and documented by the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-1-p4
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. Effective income for <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> planning to retire during the first three-year period must include the amount of: a. Documented retirement benefits; b. Social Security payments; or c. Other payments expected to be received in retirement. ii. <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">Creditors</ref> must not ask the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> about possible, future maternity leave. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-2
paragraph.title: Overtime and Bonus Income.
paragraph.content: Overtime and Bonus Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-2-a
paragraph.content: Overtime and bonus income can be used to qualify the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> if he/she has received this income for the past two years, and it will likely continue. If the employment verification <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">states</ref> that the overtime and bonus income is unlikely to continue, it may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-2-b
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must develop an average of bonus or overtime income for the past two years. Periods of overtime and bonus income less than two years may be acceptable, provided the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> can justify and document in writing the reason for using the income for qualifying purposes.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-3
paragraph.title: Establishing an Overtime and Bonus Income Earning Trend.
paragraph.content: Establishing an Overtime and Bonus Income Earning Trend.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-3-a
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must establish and document an earnings trend for overtime and bonus income. If either type of income shows a continual decline, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must document in writing a sound rationalization for including the income when qualifying the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-3-b
paragraph.content: A period of more than two years must be used in calculating the average overtime and bonus income if the income varies significantly from year to year.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-4
paragraph.title: Qualifying Part-Time Income.
paragraph.content: Qualifying Part-Time Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-4-a
paragraph.content: Part-time and seasonal income can be used to qualify the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> if the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> documents that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> has worked the part-time job uninterrupted for the past two years, and plans to continue. Many low and moderate income families rely on part-time and seasonal income for day to day needs, and <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditors</ref> should not restrict consideration of such income when qualifying these <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-4-b
paragraph.content: Part-time income received for less than two years may be included as effective income, provided that the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> justifies and documents that the income is likely to continue.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-4-c
paragraph.content: Part-time income not meeting the qualifying requirements may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-4-p5
paragraph.content: ```note Note: For qualifying purposes, “part-time” income refers to employment taken to supplement the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income from regular employment; part-time employment is not a primary job and it is worked less than 40 hours. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5
paragraph.title: Income from Seasonal Employment.
paragraph.content: Income from Seasonal Employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-a
paragraph.content: Seasonal income is considered uninterrupted, and may be used to qualify the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>, if the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> documents that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-a-i
paragraph.content: Has worked the same job for the past two years, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-a-ii
paragraph.content: Expects to be rehired the next season.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-b
paragraph.content: Seasonal employment includes:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-b-i
paragraph.content: Umpiring baseball games in the summer; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-5-b-ii
paragraph.content: Working at a department store during the holiday shopping season.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-6
paragraph.title: Primary Employment Less Than 40 Hour Work Week.
paragraph.content: Primary Employment Less Than 40 Hour Work Week.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-6-a
paragraph.content: When a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s primary employment is less than a typical 40-hour work week, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> should evaluate the stability of that income as regular, on-going primary employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-6-b
paragraph.content: Example: A registered nurse may have worked 24 hours per week for the last year. Although this job is less than the 40-hour work week, it is the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s primary employment, and should be considered effective income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7
paragraph.title: Commission Income.
paragraph.content: Commission Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-a
paragraph.content: Commission income must be averaged over the previous two years. To qualify commission income, the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> must provide:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-a-i
paragraph.content: Copies of signed tax returns for the last two years; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-a-ii
paragraph.content: The most recent pay stub.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-b
paragraph.content: <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumers</ref> whose commission income was received for more than one year, but less than two years may be considered favorably if the underwriter can:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-b-i
paragraph.content: Document the likelihood that the income will continue, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-b-ii
paragraph.content: Soundly rationalize accepting the commission income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-7-b-p6
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. Unreimbursed business expenses must be subtracted from gross income. ii. A commissioned <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is one who receives more than 25 percent of his/her annual income from commissions. iii. A tax transcript obtained directly from the IRS may be used in lieu of signed tax returns, and the cost of the transcript may be charged to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-8
paragraph.title: Qualifying Commission Income Earned for Less Than One Year.
paragraph.content: Qualifying Commission Income Earned for Less Than One Year.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-8-a
paragraph.content: Commission income earned for less than one year is not considered effective income. Exceptions may be made for situations in which the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> was changed from salary to commission within a similar position with the same employer.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-8-b
paragraph.content: A <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> may also qualify when the portion of earnings not attributed to commissions would be sufficient to qualify the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> for the mortgage.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-9
paragraph.title: Employer Differential Payments.
paragraph.content: Employer Differential Payments. If the employer subsidizes a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s mortgage payment through direct payments, the amount of the payments:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-9-a
paragraph.content: Is considered gross income, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-9-b
paragraph.content: Cannot be used to offset the mortgage payment directly, even if the employer pays the servicing <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> directly.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-10
paragraph.title: Retirement Income.
paragraph.content: Retirement Income. Retirement income must be verified from the former employer, or from Federal tax returns. If any retirement income, such as employer pensions or 401(k)'s, will cease within the first full three years of the mortgage loan, such income may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-11
paragraph.title: Social Security Income.
paragraph.content: Social Security Income. Social Security income must be verified by the Social Security Administration or on Federal tax returns. If any benefits expire within the first full three years of the loan, the income source may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12
paragraph.title: Automobile Allowances and Expense Account Payments.
paragraph.content: Automobile Allowances and Expense Account Payments.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-a
paragraph.content: Only the amount by which the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s automobile allowance or expense account payments exceed actual expenditures may be considered income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-b
paragraph.content: To establish the amount to add to gross income, the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> must provide the following:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-b-i
paragraph.content: IRS Form 2106, Employee Business Expenses, for the previous two years; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-b-ii
paragraph.content: Employer verification that the payments will continue.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-c
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> uses the standard per-mile rate in calculating automobile expenses, as opposed to the actual cost method, the portion that the IRS considers depreciation may be added back to income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-d
paragraph.content: Expenses that must be treated as recurring debt include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-d-i
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s monthly car payment; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-12-d-ii
paragraph.content: Any loss resulting from the calculation of the difference between the actual expenditures and the expense account allowance.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-B-p7
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must obtain a complete copy of the current awards letter. ii. Not all Social Security income is for retirement-aged recipients; therefore, documented continuation is required. iii. Some portion of Social Security income may be “grossed up” if deemed nontaxable by the IRS. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C
paragraph.content: <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumers</ref> Employed by a Family Owned Business.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-1
paragraph.title: Income Documentation Requirement.
paragraph.content: Income Documentation Requirement.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-p8
paragraph.content: In addition to normal employment verification, a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> employed by a family owned business is required to provide evidence that he/she is not an owner of the business, which may include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-p8-a
paragraph.content: Copies of signed personal tax returns, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-p8-b
paragraph.content: A signed copy of the corporate tax return showing ownership percentage.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-C-p8-p9
paragraph.content: ```note Note:A tax transcript obtained directly from the IRS may be used in lieu of signed tax returns, and the cost of the transcript may be charged to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D
paragraph.content: General Information on Self-Employed <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumers</ref> and Income Analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-1
paragraph.title: Definition: Self Employed Consumer.
paragraph.content: Definition: Self Employed <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref>. A <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> with a 25 percent or greater ownership interest in a business is considered self-employed.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2
paragraph.title: Types of Business Structures.
paragraph.content: Types of Business Structures. There are four basic types of business structures. They include:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2-a
paragraph.content: Sole proprietorships;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2-b
paragraph.content: Corporations;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2-c
paragraph.content: Limited liability or “S” corporations; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-2-d
paragraph.content: Partnerships.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-3
paragraph.title: Minimum Length of Self Employment.
paragraph.content: Minimum Length of Self Employment.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-3-a
paragraph.content: Income from self-employment is considered stable, and effective, if the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> has been self-employed for two or more years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-3-b
paragraph.content: Due to the high probability of failure during the first few years of a business, the requirements described in the table below are necessary for <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> who have been self-employed for less than two years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4
paragraph.title: General Documentation Requirements for Self Employed Consumers.
paragraph.content: General Documentation Requirements for Self Employed <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumers</ref>. Self-employed <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumers</ref> must provide the following documentation:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4-a
paragraph.content: Signed, dated individual tax returns, with all applicable tax schedules for the most recent two years;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4-b
paragraph.content: For a corporation, “S” corporation, or partnership, signed copies of Federal business income tax returns for the last two years, with all applicable tax schedules;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4-c
paragraph.content: Year to date profit and loss (P&L) statement and balance sheet; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-4-d
paragraph.content: Business <ref target="1026-2-a-14" reftype="term">credit</ref> report for corporations and “S” corporations.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5
paragraph.title: Establishing a Consumer's Earnings Trend.
paragraph.content: Establishing a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref>'s Earnings Trend.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-a
paragraph.content: When qualifying a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> for a mortgage loan, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must establish the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s earnings trend from the previous two years using the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s tax returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-b
paragraph.content: If a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-b-i
paragraph.content: Provides quarterly tax returns, the income analysis may include income through the period covered by the tax filings, or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-b-ii
paragraph.content: Is not subject to quarterly tax returns, or does not file them, then the income shown on the P&L statement may be included in the analysis, provided the income stream based on the P&L is consistent with the previous years' earnings.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-c
paragraph.content: If the P&L statements submitted for the current year show an income stream considerably greater than what is supported by the previous year's tax returns, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must base the income analysis solely on the income verified through the tax returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-5-d
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s earnings trend for the previous two years is downward and the most recent tax return or P&L is less than the prior year's tax return, the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s most recent year's tax return or P&L must be used to calculate his/her income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6
paragraph.title: Analyzing the Business's Financial Strength:
paragraph.content: Analyzing the Business's Financial Strength:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6-a
paragraph.content: To determine if the business is expected to generate sufficient income for the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s needs, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must carefully analyze the business's financial strength, including the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6-a-i
paragraph.content: Source of the business's income;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6-a-ii
paragraph.content: General economic outlook for similar businesses in the area.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-D-6-b
paragraph.content: Annual earnings that are stable or increasing are acceptable, while businesses that show a significant decline in income over the analysis period are not acceptable.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-E
paragraph.content: Income Analysis: Individual Tax Returns (IRS Form 1040).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-E-1
paragraph.title: General Policy on Adjusting Income Based on a Review of IRS Form 1040.
paragraph.content: General Policy on Adjusting Income Based on a Review of IRS Form 1040. The amount shown on a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s IRS Form 1040 as adjusted gross income must either be increased or decreased based on the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref>'s analysis of the individual tax return and any related tax schedules.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-E-2
paragraph.title: Guidelines for Analyzing IRS Form 1040.
paragraph.content: Guidelines for Analyzing IRS Form 1040. The table below contains guidelines for analyzing IRS Form 1040:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F
paragraph.content: Income Analysis: Corporate Tax Returns (IRS Form 1120).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-1
paragraph.title: Description: Corporation.
paragraph.content: Description: Corporation. A corporation is a <ref target="1026-2-a-26" reftype="term">State</ref>-chartered business owned by its stockholders.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2
paragraph.title: Need To Obtain Consumer Percentage of Ownership Information.
paragraph.content: Need To Obtain <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">Consumer</ref> Percentage of Ownership Information.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2-a
paragraph.content: Corporate <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> to the officers, generally in proportion to the percentage of ownership, is shown on the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2-a-i
paragraph.content: Corporate tax return IRS Form 1120; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2-a-ii
paragraph.content: Individual tax returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-2-b
paragraph.content: When a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s percentage of ownership does not appear on the tax returns, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must obtain the information from the corporation's accountant, along with evidence that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> has the right to any <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref>.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3
paragraph.title: Analyzing Corporate Tax Returns.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Corporate Tax Returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-a
paragraph.content: In order to determine a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s self-employed income from a corporation the adjusted business income must:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-a-i
paragraph.content: Be determined; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Multiplied by the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s percentage of ownership in the business.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-F-3-b
paragraph.content: The table below describes the items found on IRS Form 1120 for which an adjustment must be made in order to determine adjusted business income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G
paragraph.content: Income Analysis: “S” Corporation Tax Returns (IRS Form 1120S).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-1
paragraph.title: Description: “S” Corporation.
paragraph.content: Description: “S” Corporation.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-1-a
paragraph.content: An “S” corporation is generally a small, start-up business, with gains and losses passed to stockholders in proportion to each stockholder's percentage of business ownership.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-1-b
paragraph.content: Income for owners of “S” corporations comes from IRS Form W-2 wages, and is taxed at the individual rate. The IRS Form 1120S, <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">Compensation</ref> of Officers line item is transferred to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s individual IRS Form 1040.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-2
paragraph.title: Analyzing “S” Corporation Tax Returns.
paragraph.content: Analyzing “S” Corporation Tax Returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-2-a
paragraph.content: “S” corporation depreciation and depletion may be added back to income in proportion to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s share of the corporation's income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-2-b
paragraph.content: In addition, the income must also be reduced proportionately by the total obligations payable by the corporation in less than one year.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-G-2-c
paragraph.content: Important: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s withdrawal of cash from the corporation may have a severe negative impact on the corporation's ability to continue operating, and must be considered in the income analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H
paragraph.content: Income Analysis: Partnership Tax Returns (IRS Form 1065).

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-1
paragraph.title: Description: Partnership.
paragraph.content: Description: Partnership.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-1-a
paragraph.content: A partnership is formed when two or more individuals form a business, and share in profits, losses, and responsibility for running the company.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-1-b
paragraph.content: Each partner pays taxes on his/her proportionate share of the partnership's net income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2
paragraph.title: Analyzing Partnership Tax Returns.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Partnership Tax Returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-a
paragraph.content: Both general and limited partnerships report income on IRS Form 1065, and the partners' share of income is carried over to Schedule E of IRS Form 1040.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-b
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must review IRS Form 1065 to assess the viability of the business. Both depreciation and depletion may be added back to the income in proportion to the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s share of income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-c
paragraph.content: Income must also be reduced proportionately by the total obligations payable by the partnership in less than one year.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h1-H-2-d
paragraph.content: Important: Cash withdrawals from the partnership may have a severe negative impact on the partnership's ability to continue operating, and must be considered in the income analysis.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A
paragraph.content: Alimony, Child Support, and Maintenance Income Criteria. Alimony, child support, or maintenance income may be considered effective, if:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-1
paragraph.content: Payments are likely to be received consistently for the first three years of the mortgage;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> provides the required documentation, which includes a copy of the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-i
paragraph.content: Final divorce decree;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-ii
paragraph.content: Legal separation agreement;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-iii
paragraph.content: Court order; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-2-iv
paragraph.content: Voluntary payment agreement; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3
paragraph.content: The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> can provide acceptable evidence that payments have been received during the last 12 months, such as:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-i
paragraph.content: Cancelled checks;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-ii
paragraph.content: Deposit slips;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-iii
paragraph.content: Tax returns; or

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-iv
paragraph.content: Court records.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-A-3-p13
paragraph.content: ```note Notes: i. Periods less than 12 months may be acceptable, provided the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> can adequately document the payer's ability and willingness to make timely payments. ii. Child support may be “grossed up” under the same provisions as non-taxable income sources. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B
paragraph.content: Investment and Trust Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-1
paragraph.title: Analyzing Interest and Dividends.
paragraph.content: Analyzing Interest and Dividends.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-1-a
paragraph.content: Interest and dividend income may be used as long as tax returns or account statements support a two-year receipt history. This income must be averaged over the two years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-1-b
paragraph.content: Subtract any funds that are derived from these sources, and are required for the cash investment, before calculating the projected interest or dividend income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2
paragraph.title: Trust Income.
paragraph.content: Trust Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-a
paragraph.content: Income from trusts may be used if guaranteed, constant payments will continue for at least the first three years of the mortgage term.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b
paragraph.content: Required trust income documentation includes a copy of the Trust Agreement or other trustee statement, confirming the:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b-i
paragraph.content: Amount of the trust;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b-ii
paragraph.content: Frequency of distribution; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-b-iii
paragraph.content: Duration of payments.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-2-c
paragraph.content: Trust account funds may be used for the required cash investment if the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> provides adequate documentation that the withdrawal of funds will not negatively affect income. The <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> may use funds from the trust account for the required cash investment, but the trust income used to determine repayment ability cannot be affected negatively by its use.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3
paragraph.title: Notes Receivable Income.
paragraph.content: Notes Receivable Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-a
paragraph.content: In order to include notes receivable income to qualify a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>, he/she must provide:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-a-i
paragraph.content: A copy of the note to establish the amount and length of payment, and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-a-ii
paragraph.content: Evidence that these payments have been consistently received for the last 12 months through deposit slips, cancelled checks, or tax returns.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-3-b
paragraph.content: If the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is not the original payee on the note, the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> must establish that the <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref> is now a holder in due course, and able to enforce the note.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-4
paragraph.title: Eligible Investment Properties.
paragraph.content: Eligible Investment Properties.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-B-p14
paragraph.content: Follow the steps in the table below to calculate an investment property's income or loss if the property to be subject to a mortgage is an eligible investment property.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C
paragraph.content: Military, Government Agency, and Assistance Program Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1
paragraph.title: Military Income.
paragraph.content: Military Income.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a
paragraph.content: Military personnel not only receive base pay, butoftentimes are entitled to additional forms of pay, such as:

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-i
paragraph.content: Income from variable housing allowances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-ii
paragraph.content: Clothing allowances;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-iii
paragraph.content: Flight or hazard pay;

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-iv
paragraph.content: Rations; and

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-a-v
paragraph.content: Proficiency pay.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-b
paragraph.content: These types of additional pay are acceptable when analyzing a <ref target="1026-2-a-11" reftype="term">consumer</ref>'s income as long as the probability of such pay to continue is verified in writing.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-1-p16
paragraph.content: ```note Note:The tax-exempt nature of some of the above payments should also be considered. ```

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2
paragraph.title: VA Benefits.
paragraph.content: VA Benefits.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2-a
paragraph.content: Direct <ref target="1026-36-a-3" reftype="term">compensation</ref> for service-related disabilities from the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) is acceptable, provided the <ref target="1026-2-a-17" reftype="term">creditor</ref> receives documentation from the VA.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-2-b
paragraph.content: Education benefits used to offset education expenses are not acceptable.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3
paragraph.title: Government Assistance Programs.
paragraph.content: Government Assistance Programs.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-a
paragraph.content: Income received from government assistance programs is acceptable as long as the paying agency provides documentation indicating that the income is expected to continue for at least three years.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-b
paragraph.content: If the income from government assistance programs will not be received for at least three years, it may not be used in qualifying.

paragraph.label: 1026-Q-h2-C-3-c
